million euros to help measures
government clamped down on the migrant
road but smuggling hasn't gone away it's

hello is anybody speak English who are

where are you going next you're going to

all they seem to know about the journey

any idea
about Libya about the horrors that await
them had no idea about the Sahara they
had no idea about the Mediterranean Sea
and how many died in it the EU is trying
to cut the number of migrants crossing
the Mediterranean and it seems to be
working
figures just released by the
International Organization for Migration
show that just four thousand cross from
Libya to Italy this August compared to
21 thousand last year the EU are trying
to tackle the problem at source the
smuggling trade was a big part of the
agadez economy and the EU is investing
in former smugglers who want to launch a
business I joined the meeting overseen
by Nigerian and EU officials which was
attended by those claiming to be
eligible for funding 6000 euros at a
time to move from smuggling into any
professional they wish for example they
can say they want to be a mechanic and
only give him money to become one but
privately I was told the project has
flaws it's difficult to monitor how the
money is spent and checking who's
actually a former smuggler is hard it
seems almost anyone can claim to be one
I was even told that someone drove from
Mali to get money claiming to be a
Nigerian smuggler
the EU can fend to us that they are
providing funding for ex smugglers to
build businesses but say they don't hand
out any cash the dangers faced by those
trying to make it to Europe
what brought home to me when I tried to
rejoin the group of people at metalia I
was told they were waiting in the Sahara
to begin the journey but a storm flooded
the route we had to turn back the next
day we heard at least seven migrants
were reported to have died in the desert
overnight we'll never know if that
included any of the people we've met the
numbers reaching Italy may have fallen
dramatically for now but new routes are
already being found and around the
million migrants are still trapped in
Libya hoping for a new life in Europe
